O'er the long lapse of ages to look back,</br>To wind and wander thro' each dark recess,</br>The mind's untutor'd feelings there to track,</br>Rambling o'er nature, rob'd in simplest dress,</br>'Tis sweet! — and then those savage virtues guess,</br>Which, ripen'd by the autumnal touch of time,</br>Lose not their bright primeval loveliness,</br>But cast their rough rind, and a charm sublime</br>Sweeps o'er them! — May my muse unveil that generous prime!

Deep in the frozen regions of the north,</br>I then beheld thee, Scotia! — as of yore;</br>Towering majestic o'er thy billowy Forth,</br>Flashing thy lightnings round thy stormy shore:</br>Above thee, Ossian floated; and the power</br>Of song from Selma wak'd again the brave;</br>And Loda's might from Scandinavia, bore</br>Thy fearful glories: — o'er thine ocean's cave</br>His dreadful spirit hung; — then trembling roll'd thy wave.

His beard was whiter than the driven snow;</br>Seem'd it the foam which round his Hebrides</br>The whirlwinds breathe; and from his eyes' red glow</br>Started a flame, as from the topaz blaze.</br>So glares the red sun thro' a morning's haze;</br>Like Alpine skies in winter's northern night,</br>So streak'd his furrowed face: — a meteors rays</br>Embrac'd his forehead; and the ambient light,</br>Pure as the path of Heaven, evolved its floods so bright.

O'er Scotia's sea-girt throne he bent his might,</br>Flashing around her, streams of radiance flow'd!</br>Hush'd was the stormy north-wind; and the light</br>Of Heaven's meridian met his awful nod.</br>Upon her brow a beam of glory rode,</br>The radiance of her sons; — and by her side</br>Stern Independence stood; and look'd abroad</br>O'er mountain, vale, and ocean's stormy tide;</br>She sunk within his fold, as would a blushing bride:

Before her eye a magic glass was plac'd,</br>Which both the past and future held to view;</br>And there, the virtues of her sons were trac'd,</br>Whose fires like pent volcanoes stronger grew.</br>That eye, the lightning's rapid flash, she threw</br>Where flagg'd the Roman eagle's fainting wing;</br>As up the Grampian toiling, to pursue</br>The awful echoes which around him ring;</br>Its haggard's fearful glances made it backward swing.

Above her, — but the naked vault of Heaven;</br>Around her, — storm; — the cold — the barren heath;</br>Her wood, — her Druid; — to whose mind was given</br>The power of inspiration, and its breath.</br>And curl'd the ice-cloud up her mountain-path;</br>And from its torturing volume glanc'd an eye,</br>Which, like the angel of Almighty wrath,</br>Sprung on the soul of life; — then down her sky</br>Rush'd Independence; — soon, the foeman fled his cry.

Pillar'd beside her stood he, like the rock</br>Lifting its steep front o'er the mountain-wave,</br>Firm in the heavings of its ocean's shock;</br>Towering, — the billows round its bosom lay;</br>The toiling eddy trembles; — on its grave</br>Of foam, dark spirits lean; — the waves back fly,</br>In convoluted circles; — murmuring, rave</br>The angry whirlwinds; — from the depths, on high,</br>The bleaching storms are chas'd; — and muttering pass they by.

Rush'd he across her Firths? — Her waves reply,</br>Bending their billows to their wintry shore;</br>Along her wilds he roamed; his piercing eye</br>Kindled, as shook her heath, its purple flower.</br>He flam'd a meteor o'er her fields of gore;—</br>He breath'd; — and Heaven obedient to his nod,</br>Op'd the recesses of each hidden store;</br>And, thro' the crimson of their evening cloud,</br>Smile would each hero's ghost, as thro' its mist they rode.

What pass — what height — what forest — or what glen,</br>Sends not its dread memorial far abroad?</br>Boil'd high the blood of each advent'rous clan,</br>Erect they stood, and bent alone to GOD.</br>Majestic stept they! — Earth they lightly trod</br>Their eye, their heart, their soul, proud Scotia!  thine;</br>How many thousands sleep beneath their sod;</br>Unknown, unnoticed tho' life's swift decline,</br>Whose record might have been for future times — a sign!

Needs not the blazon of thine ancient fame,</br>To blow the trumpet of thy dread renown,</br>Thy glories brighter live, — as solar flame</br>Bursting from sleep, — refresh'd — more vig'rous grown.</br>Heroes of former times!  thy wreaths are thrown</br>O'er the broad summits of each cloud-cap'd mound;</br>Nor stole thy sons thy fires; — they boast their own;</br>From India's torrid climes their names resound,</br>To where each frozen pole in wintry horror's crown'd.

Thy path was glorious! — glorious still its shine!</br>Who has not heard of Scotia's mountain land?</br>As thro' their length'ning course deep streams refine,</br>Brighter from age thy radiant flames expand.</br>Where pours the Nile upon her Egypt's strand,</br>Thy name shall live, if virtue ne'er can die!</br>And Abercromby's spirit there shall stand,</br>(Like the canopus of the eastern sky)</br>A pharos, — lighting up Gallia's deep tragedy.

In days of yore, — when yet thy fields were waste,</br>And o'er thy dreams the memory of thy sires</br>Would come, like sun-beams thro' an ice-cloud trac'd,</br>Melting and radiant, and their blush like fires</br>Holy as Vesta's, — as the flame which spires</br>Red as the cresset, from its beacon's height;—</br>In days of yore, — these dreams, like angels' lyres,</br>Wak'd unto glory, stole upon the night,</br>And bore the list'ning spirit to etherial light.

Thy mountain then spread out its giant's form,</br>Thy rock stood frowning o'er the vale below,</br>Thy cataract of foam, like winter's storm,</br>Swept down thy pass, like arrow from the bow:</br>And the harsh winds of heaven, in fearful flow,</br>Rush'd onwards; met their shrieks thy daring soul;</br>And when thy sun shone forth in winter's glow,</br>And wreath'd the clouds their black and angry scroll;—</br>Rock, river, mountain, stream, the winds, as burst their roll,

In angry whirls, along the threat'ning sky,</br>All spoke a language to the boiling blood,</br>That inspiration, fastening on the eye,</br>Deem'd, in its mountain-rock, its toiling flood,</br>Its mist which o'er the foaming cataract stood,</br>The warrior of departed days still there;</br>His wild eyes flashing thro' these scenes so rude,</br>Kindling to flame; as bursting from his lair,</br>His spirit rush'd abroad, to feed thy mountain air.

'Twas awful, from thy glens of virgin snow,</br>Where, rose the lone hut by the fretting rill,</br>To hear the muttering night breeze trembling throw</br>Its eddies, rock'd by silence, round its hill.</br>To mark the cold and spectral moon-beam spill</br>Its ray upon its broad stalactic rock;</br>And Fancy, wandering o'er thy northern chill,</br>Catch fairy visions from each ice-clad block,</br>And deem thy Genii there, where'er their lightnings broke!

How lovely then, to watch thy blue eyed maid</br>Her softer radiance on the cold beam throw</br>To watch her star point down the winding glade,</br>To light her thro' her wilderness of snow!</br>Red bursts the moon, and waves the bloody glow</br>On Alpine height — that fearful echo hark,</br>As speeds the cross of fire the clansman's blow</br>A thousand flames now shiver from one spark,</br>Light as meridian floods, and now as midnight, — dark!

She listens! — hears a footstep on the heath,</br>Quick, as the pulses from her bosom dart;</br>She stops, — she harkens, — and her panting breath</br>Flows round the billows of a bursting heart.</br>"Alice, farewell! — I dreamt not we should part!"</br>Her lips receive his last impassion'd kiss;</br>The yells of battle on the mountain start;</br>And now 'tis calm, as on the fields of bliss;</br>The world of spirits, theirs; — they've bid adieu to this.

Ye! — over whom a thousand years have past,</br>Yet, can I trace you on your lonely hill,</br>Up cataract's foaming arch, up mountain waste,</br>Thro' dark deep pass, along yet darker rill;</br>Thro' mists long leaning on your winters chill;</br>When o'er the ridges of you frowning steep</br>Scowl'd the black forest's brow, — and breathless, still,</br>Round and around, rush'd silence, like the sweep</br>That takes the thunder cloud, when lightnings from it leap.

Now, thou lone crag, — thou tyrant of the glen,</br>Whose cloud-cap'd head primeval worlds has seen,</br>Bald is thy crown, and savage is thy ken,</br>Where once thy forests wav'd in Summer's green.</br>The mountain deer upon thy rock still lean;</br>Sweep they like meteors o'er thy ridge of snow;</br>Like the sharp moon, whose horns of silver sheen,</br>Emerging from their cloud, with sudden glow</br>Glimmer, — then veil their light, — and all is dark below.

Yet, o'er these ridges, crown'd with cliffs of snow,</br>A wizard rises; — stern and grim his air,—</br>A gnarled oak, deprived of bark and bough,</br>Him, times remotest still have witness'd there.</br>He, the last remnant of the wild boar's lair,</br>Stands, like the withering spectre of the night,</br>On whom the sheeted dead, with hollow stare,</br>Fix their glar'd orbs, — proud of his ancient might,</br>His prostrate woods he views, like heroes fallen in fight.

His throne, — 'tis silence; — and his wild domain</br>One lifeless dreary solitude; — around</br>Hush'd are the sleeping skies; — his ancient reign</br>Lost, like a far off dream in night profound.</br>Close by, a lake, — veil'd by a rocky mound,</br>Whose dead swart pool, his deep divining glass,</br>In which the past is trac'd, the future found,</br>And on the bare crag leaning o'er the mass</br>Of waters, towers his eagle, — guardian of the pass.

The clouds that blend their horrors on its breast,</br>And blacken all beneath; — the winter's rush,</br>In fearful tempest, when the sunless crest,</br>Rocks, — and the valleys fear some sudden crush;</br>Summer's unclouded hue; — the lonely hush</br>Of morn and even, serve that wizard's spell</br>And thro' each dripping cave and gorse-clad bush,</br>Thro' every winding of the lonely fell,</br>Songs of old times revive, — echo prolongs their swell.

How lovely!  o'er these glens of virgin snow,</br>To dream of bygone days, those times explore,</br>When high born-spirits, flashing freedom's glow,</br>Burst like the wild winds o'er their ice-clad shore,</br>To view the proud unbending man of yore,</br>Rude, firm, unshaken in his head-strong way,</br>With mind untutor'd, skill'd in nature's lore,</br>His generous bosom open as the day,</br>Leaning on Heaven's bright cope, and cherished by its ray!

Thy path was in the whirlwind, and thy breath,</br>The lightning's touch; — thine eye, — the tempest's flood;</br>Thy word, — an angel's pledge; — the blast of death</br>Burst in its dread convulsion, at thy nod.</br>And where thy foot on hill or valley trod,</br>Thy step was firm; — thine air, a monarch's crest;</br>Tho' lodg'd in cavern hoar, thy spirit rode</br>Above thine eagle's ken; — mind, feeling press'd</br>Towards the vault of Heaven; — and Heaven alone address'd,

Ah!  then that spirit was the soul of fame,</br>Rich in the treasures of thy powerful mind;</br>Harsh tho' thy features, hardy was thy frame,</br>Thy freeborn sons — the first of human kind.</br>For independence only could thee bind:</br>No iron bondage chain'd thy daring hand;</br>Thy soul roam'd freely, like thy wintry wind,</br>And tho' thy rock was naked, and thy land</br>Barren; — the hearts it nourish'd knew each virtue bland.

A day of storm was thine; — the storm has past</br>Spring's halcyon breath is shower'd on winter's tread;</br>And thy clear streams embosom'd are, at last,</br>In valleys, glist'ning from their emerald bed.</br>And the bleak hills, on which our fathers bled,</br>Wave their brown ringlets o'er the golden grain;</br>And thy deep bays, with floating cities clad,</br>Launch joyous on the surges of the main,</br>The riches of thy floods, the treasures of thy plain.

Peace smiles upon thy vales, — sweeps up thy hills,</br>Art's plastic hand adorns thy lovely bowers;</br>Thy tractless wilds — yet fed by pebbly rills,</br>Thy mountains — scented by their purple flowers.</br>The heath-cock's call, there — morn and evening — pours;</br>The erne finds yet its aerie on their crest;</br>And silence also dreams its lonely hours;</br>And the like storms of yore that swept thy breast,</br>Frown; — but where nature gloom'd, find now a flowery vest.

And where that mind, and where that stubborn heart</br>Which ages nourish'd in each wild retreat?—</br>Temper'd and soften'd! — o'er each zone they dart</br>Their influence, and each virtue emulate.</br>Patient and cheerful in each changing state;</br>Children of every clime, abroad they roam;</br>From Pole to Pole pursue their hidden fate,</br>Dream of their birchen bowers, their Alpine home,</br>Midst polar snows, — midst suns that fire the equator's dome.

But the same blood which in their fathers' veins</br>Boil'd, — in their offspring will its course pursue;</br>And nature, whilst its vigor still remains,</br>The same warm blood will to its task be true.</br>Thy mountain spirit, Scotia!  round thee drew</br>Almighty Freedom; — hark! — its hallowed strain</br>Smiling upon thy rock's grey breast, she grew,</br>Spread like the winds of heaven, o'er hill and plain;</br>And bore aloft that mind, — never to fall again.

Scotia!  thy lone and silent hills I view,</br>As the mind's eye thro' promis'd bliss will swim;</br>The whispering of thy floods I still pursue,</br>Like the rapt seer in his wand'ring dream,</br>Thou com'st upon me, like the sun's last gleam,</br>Soften'd yet splendid: —  on its sloping ray</br>I mount; — and, lighted by its purpl'd stream,</br>Look on the days of old! — Attend my lay!</br>And may thy spirit wing me on my adventurous way!</br>
